text: Thanks for the reply <@U09T8SFG8> :taco:
I think this is something that depends to much on the use case to display in a general demo
So if I understand correctly, you use RxJava's `replay` to do the caching, correct?
ye
that should be good then, for my case I wanted more flexibility and I am also caching in a db
Ye, caching in a db is an alternative.
But also depends on the requirements
I will display my whole class so I can make it a bit more clear how my repositories are structured
And replay could still be used on a config change
This is the whole file, I just replaced the actual structure with "Entity" just to make it more clear <https://gist.github.com/AkiKanellis/7323efba9b8c2311fee6aa3adc13ba53>
So basically I have 3 repositories
One for network, it uses the network api and a mapper to map the data
One for disk which does the db stuff
and the diskcached one which uses the two of them in conjuction
so my use cases for now only use the EntityDiskCachedRepository
but if I wanted to switch in network only I would just switch to using the EntityNetworkRepository

At first I did the horrible mistake of trying to have the same interface for all 3 repositories because it would make switching between them extremely easy. This is possible in some cases, specifically when you have complete control over the data (I do this exact thing in another part of the app) but in most cases you don't want the same interface because for example my NetworkRepository has the ability to fetch but not insert while the disk one has the ability for both
you dont need a super interface holding all thoes features
you can make each ‘store’ implement whatever features they support. Alternately just throw unsupported operation exceptions.

<@U055GGAHS>: yes exactly, I tried to make a super interface which basically made me end up over-engineering and making a mess. Then I switched to unsupported operation exceptions but I did not like that either since it seemed like a waste. Then I just thought that I will probably never need to quickly switch between those interfaces so I just made everything separate
<@U10KBSENS|silviu> has joined the channel
IReadableStore, IWriteableStore
I did not like that either
why?
I tried it but still it did not fit my usecase
because for example I do not need to fetch by id, so I ended up having to throw unsupported again
for example one of my use cases is to fetch by id, but only from the network and never from the disk
that is why I needed separate
Anyone here ever worked with Azure Push Notifications in Android here?
<@U09T8SFG8>: I think we should fetch data from DiskRepository first, because it makes app load data faster
It works like: load data from the disk (disk cache or sqlite, etc) after this load data from network to fetch new data.
<@U09T8SFG8> lol I totally forgot about our convo because I was so focused on my work :smile:

I would say that depends solely on the data and what user experience you want. For me, the disk is just a backup and the data gets updated online very frequently therefore I always want the network data first
<@U09T8SFG8>: thanks for sharing. I read trough your discussion with ian, I guess it depends a lot on the use case if you can have a super interface
I just ran into a similar problem, but it was purely because I wanted to showcase the same architecture with and without rx
Callbacks don’t mix with rx :smile:
Anyway <@U09T8SFG8> thanks for sharing have some more tacos :taco:
yeah, valid point
yeiii tacos
Hmm
I had made a setup once where I launched a disk query and a network query at the same time
Depending on what returned first I showed that first
and if network call came back later (which normally is the case) I just updated the UI accordingly and updated my db accordingly
It works extremely well once it is set up. And wasn’t to bad to do with Rx
There are several solutions, and also depends if you have control over the backend or not etc etc
But that is the ultimate setup in my opinion.
Doing disk first, and after network will work relatively the same. But in purely in theory is less desirably because your network (latest updated data) will arrive later

text: whoo!

Does anyone know if is better to have all your dimens, string, colors in one file (but organized) Or have multiple dimens, strings, colors files, named after a feature and containing feature specific content?
depends on the size of everything.
do it by feature
I’d say keep them in a single file - strings.xml, dimens.xml, etc..  - so you have a single source of truth. Until that becomes unwieldy, at which point split them.
if its’ already unwieldy, split them :simple_smile:
like the way you should keep everything in one activity? :simple_smile:
wanna take your strings one step further, take a read of this :mindblown: <https://www.novoda.com/blog/maintaining-string-resources-with-translation-in-mind/>

when I have the min / max API desginated in manifest file
[1:55] 
but project build target targets an API version older than max API version in manifest
what sort of problems occur / if any when product build is different from manifest min/max?
stackexchange mentions possible inconsistencies, but was fairly vague

minSdk only says that your app will need at least this version to run on. targetSdk says you have tested your app on this and it's safe for the system to assume you don't need any backwards compatibility. you generally always want to target the latest SDK available
docs are vague on the compatibility modes too
